title: Between 5 July 2019 and 31 December 2019, will McDonald's announce that it will offer an alternative protein vegetarian burger in the United States?
preds: As mentioned, they do it in Europe already and pressure is enormous. Even if it would not sell - they will offer it

"Plant-based burgers will make men grow boobs, Livestock News reports..."[1] Feature, not a bug? [1] https://arstechnica.com/science/2019/12/plant-based-burgers-will-make-men-grow-boobs-livestock-news-reports/

McDonald's Plant-Based Burger Trial Isn't a Slam Dunk, Analyst Suggests Pomranz (2019) Oct. 31, stated that: Despite being the most successful fast food restaurant on the planet, McDonald's has a history of adding products people don't want. (I'm old enough to remember the Arch Deluxe!) So today's McDonald's may be warier of a big plant-based burger rollout than its competitors. And though the company is a late entry into the fake meat market, its commitment to the test phase means we're probably less likely to see a quick Dunkin'-style turnaround and a more measured rollout. If the Canada trial does turn out to be a bust, McDonald's plant-based burger timeline might get even slower. Either way, it seems the "when will McDonald's add a plant-based burger?" questions won't be going away any time soon (Para. 8).  Pomranz, M. (2019). There's a possibility that McDonald's might offer an alternative protein burger to attract the vegetarian crowd. However:
1. There's also only 1.5 months left to the end of the year. The likelihood of this happening is decreasing every day. 
2. We're nearing the end-of-year holiday season where people are often tempted to eat unhealthily, compared to the first month of the year when people are still committed to their New Year's resolutions. It seems unlikely that McDonalds would choose this time to introduce a 'healthy' vegetarian option into their menu for the first time. 
3. Meat consumption has continued to rise in the United States over the past five decades (https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/meat-consumption-in-america.html). There are enough meat eaters to ensure that McDonalds will not need to offer a vegetarian option if it prefers not to.
They're running out of time to do it. But they will do in to keep up with the trend. Its like salad, people will go because its a healthy/good option, even though they don't pick it.

This may mean they'll decide to give it a try--not because lots of people want this product from this company, but so they can proclaim that they offer it.  Their usual customers very likely have green-thinking children and grandchildren by now, who might be counted on to agree to eat there with this stuff on offer.
Given popularity of eating less meat, big corporates need to adapt to this trend to continue to be relevant to thier customers. So they will need to provide this option or risk losing market share.

It took a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet in the United States just five hours to sell all its plant-based "fried chicken" on Aug 27, when the fast-food chain tested its first vegan product. Named Beyond Fried Chicken, the new product, sold at a store in Atlanta, Georgia, was the result of a partnership between KFC and Beyond Meat, a Los Angeles company that produces plant-based meat substitutes. It was the first time a plant-based chicken product had been sold at a national fast-food chain in the US.

It was recently announced that McDonald’s veggie burger—i.e., the “P.L.T.”, which stands for “plant, lettuce and tomato”—would be tested in select stores in Canada. Unlike other alternative protein sandwich pursuits, McDonald’s veggie burger involves a partnership with Beyond Meat. Already, Beyond Meat has demonstrated success with other fast-food chains. And the company does offer a greater variety of options than other plant-based burger competitors. Still, whether the McDonald’s veggie burger is a success or not has yet to be determined. If it is, then we may well see the P.L.T. in U.S. stores soon.
https://www.boldbusiness.com/nutrition/mcdonalds-veggie-burger-plant-based-burger/

Easterbrook and Katherine Fogertey from MCD 10/22/19 earnings call. Qualitatively, just seems like we still have a lot of steps to get through for a broad launch, and Management seems comfortable with Ontario as a solid test market: Katherine Fogertey, Analyst Great. Thank you. You guys started to test out the beyond plant-based burger in Canada. I'm wondering as you saw the quarter unfold, did you, I think that not having a meatless burger was a headwind to your sales. How are you thinking about that opportunity here? Thanks. Stephen Easterbrook, President and Chief Executive Officer Yes, we have -- excuse me, hey, we are interested in this, clearly. We've taken the plant-based product to Ontario,Canada. We got 28 restaurants that we only launched it with a couple of days of the quarter to go. So very early days.Clearly, there has been competitive activity, which you won't be aware of which I'm sure has helped create some more immediate interest or some shorter-term certainly response, consumer response.I guess what we're interested is really how best to position this, get a sense of the -- as they go on to flexitarian customer, really what is the appetite for this, no pun intended, but would it drive incremental visits, is it obviously just to switch out from time to time. We want to get the taste right, we want to get the marketing right, we want to get the operations right. So there's a number of important factors that we are learning quickly, and we think Ontario is a great spot, because that will give us a good read across North America, frankly, but also into the developed markets in Europe as well. So we think the read across will be beneficial and help us speed up our intelligence on this. So more to come clearly, but it's an area of interest for sure

On 9/26/19, McDonald's announced it will be conducting a 12-week test of a new plant-based burger called the P.L.T in 28 restaurants in Southwestern Ontario, starting 9/30/19. Given this step forward, I am increasing my probability to 25% that we see an announcement from the firm that they intend to offer an alternative protein vegetarian burger in the U.S. prior to 12/31/19. https://news.mcdonalds.com/news-releases/news-release-details/mcdonalds-tests-new-plant-based-burger-canada-plt Given the 12 week timeline of the test, my bases case is that the firm will run the test, collect feedback and provide a strategic update on the path forward for the U.S. in conjunction with the 4Q19 earnings release in mid February. I think there is a 10-20% probability that the firm provides some type of meaningful update on the progress of the test in conjunction with the earnings release expected to fall in Mid-November. We should be listening closely for management commentary on that date, which could lead to a material shift in probability of the question at hand.

Reasons why McD might release in 2019: 
-currently testing a plant-based burger made by Nestle in Germany, which is a major market and meat-loving country
-Nestle will release a plant-based burger in US in Sept. or Oct. of this year; McD could piggyback on their advertising
-JP Morgan and investors think Beyond Burger will ink a deal with a major fast food chain in 2019, and Beyond Burger is a rival of the brand that partnered with Burger King
-There's a customer petition with upwards of 200k signatures asking McD for a plant-based option Reasons why McD might not release in 2019: 
-McD has remained non-committal in calls with investors, saying they'll let the market decide. They've had poor results in the past with healthy food items, which may make them more cautious
-It's a logistics headache for them because stores would have to dedicate grill space to the plant burger; McD is by far the largest fast food chain, so this is more relevant to them than to others and may require more lead time to plan for a release
-They're doing fine from a sales perspective based on their current marketing and management of their core beef products; they've been actively working to pare down their menu 
-Other chains like Chipotle have declined to offer a plant-based option, citing concerns that they are too processed. Anecdotally, I believe people who care about plant-based food options feel the same way and won't be drawn to McD by a plant-based option, so they may not bring in new consumers by offering one
-Marketing-wise, I don't see the holiday season as a time to introduce healthy alternatives. A quick Google search also gave me the impression that they do a lot of releases in April. I could see them coming out with a plant burger in the early part of 2020 to capitalize on people's New Year's resolutions to eat better Ultimately, the success of the Impossible Burger seems to suggest that McD will eventually release a plant-based option, probably before the end of 2020, but I am skeptical that it will happen in the latter part of 2019. In the July earnings call transcript, there was not a single mention of this from Steve Easterbrook, nor a single question from the analysts on this topic. 
Delivery and EOTF (touchscreen) and through-time is what came through - and most focus on US operations.
And there was (to me anyway) an unusual latitude granted by Easterbrook to franchisees ("operators") in embracing the EOTF changes - indicating that too much change may already be going on for some operators.
I heard/read this as a message to the operators that "we want this to happen, but we hear you, and we know what we've been asking of you re: change in general, and modernization and delivery in particular ---so we won't get out over our skis on matters". This is way-out-there-theorizing - but if Easterbrook had something that would move the needle - I can;t see that he'd hold back.
And if analysts were pressuring Mgt for top-line growth - I would have expected at least one exploratory question from them.
So I revise my estimate slightly downwards, with a bigger revision likely following the Oct analysts' call.

I see them possibly waiting on the sidelines for several areas to flesh out a bit more. First, supply will be an ongoing issue. The early players have run out of stock several times. The most concerning to me personally is the unproven health benefits or consequences of the product. I have strong reservations regarding the genetically modified yeast that was turned down for approval several times before it was approved as Generally Recognized As Safe. For detail, I am not an anti-GMO person. I try to eat organic foods but also recognize that GMOs have actually been for the most part very helpful to society, with a small number of examples being the most malignant. The yeast in question is soy leghemoglobin. The FDA, who I don't have a lot of confidence in, expressed concern one year before launch that it had never been in the food supply before and may be an allergen, it gives me pause. If you would like to look at the actual FDA docs you can find them here...  https://web.archive.org/web/20180203024901/http://webivadownton.s3.amazonaws.com/877/4f/d/10646/072717_Impossible_Burger_FOIA_documents.pdf  For reputable full story please see here...   https://www.wired.com/story/the-impossible-burger/   As for McDonald's...they may also wait it out because if they didn't do it right away, I think they may try to stand out. Another hidden pothole for all this impossible meat it that the argument for it is that beef is much more environmentally destructive than pork or chicken. This is true, but fans of plant based meats I think will eventually be disillusioned when they learn it is very much an industrial process that is not that great for the environment. We shall see but I end believing McDonald's experienced early sourcing difficulties that may have given them pause regarding the finer details of the industry.

McDonalds is very cautious of new entries. 
US customers, despite trendy news articles, seem suspicious of this.
Nor are franchisees looking forward to the expense of redesign and re-training.
So they will want to careful - and might even elect not be on the bleeding edge of change - but to let BK and others lead the way, and to learn/profit from the experience.
Nevertheless, "meatless" has been coming into the public consciousness for more than a decade - so they will react.
McD testing in in Germany (not sure why there over other places). They already have maybe a decade's experience selling non-beef in India.  
McDonalds is baseline interested in selling food - and would not seem to be wedded to meat - as it's experience in India shows.
People, especially more established customers,  don't want to be trendy - they just want  "a burger" - and want to choose whether it has meat, or is meatless, with as little thought as it takes to choose whether to have cheese on it.
Finally -there remains a fair amount of study in kitchen redesign and cooking techniques and supply chain to get meatless meat right. India's experience should prove helpful - but probably also cautionary. These things have dollar costs and inefficiency costs that running a restaurant cannot take lightly. They do not want to drive away more customers than have already been lost to cultural changes and changing tastes.
I also sense the franchisees and C-Suite are not themselves ready - judging by public statements. To me it has to be branded as meatless meat - continuing to label it as a "veggie burger' or "vegan burger' is a culturally obtuse understanding of the matter, and will impede support by franchisees and interest by customers.

This forecast question has a limited scope.  It is about fast food vegetarian burger (McDonald) in the next 5 months.   While vegetarian burgers have been around of many years, the Impossible Meat and Beyond Meat are the two companies that generated most of the buzz recently.  This is especially the case after Beyond Meat's IPO and its stock performance afterwards.  Burger King, McDonald's main competitor, has tested its Impossible Burger in St. Louis early this year.  It has seen a 18% rise in traffic for the stores with Impossible Burger [1].  I suspect that a lot of the increase is due to curiosity.  It will have a nationwide roll out by the end of 2019.    McDonald does not sell vegetarian burgers in the US, although it sells them in Sweden and Germany [2] where 10% of the population are vegetarians.  The burgers it sells in Europe is from Nestle which will sell its vegetarian burgers in grocery stores in the US in the fall this year. There is no need for McDonald to jump into this market in a hurry.  The situation it faces is not like Microsoft missing the Internet revolution.  The market share of fast food vegetarian burgers is small compared with its main meat products.  It is more prudent to see how Burger King does with its nationwide roll out before making a decision.  It can always jump in at a later time without losing its main market share of meat burgers.  That means waiting beyond the end of the year.   However, it is likely that McDonald will announce a test market before the end of the year without a nation wide roll out.  This move allows to test its Nestle-based burgers or go for a different brand (it is not clear to me whether the Nestle vegetarian burgers taste better than Beyond and Impossible burgers, which generated most of the buzz) and placates its critics (for not offering vegetarian burgers).  [1]   https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/28/impossible-whopper-boosted-burger-king-traffic-by-18percent-report-says.html
[2]   https://fortune.com/2019/06/06/mcdonalds-meatless-burger-vegan/

First, as a vegetarian I have to be careful not to succumb to bias. So I proceed as usual systematically but with extra care. ~~~
Outside view
~~~ Reference class: major burger chain to offer a meatless patty burger. List of 10 biggest burger chains [1] (excluding Dairy Queen as it seems a somewhat different category). Out of those, 4 have meatless options [6].  Data: Chain	Meatless patty option?
Mcdonalds	0
Burger King	1
Wendys	0
Sonic Drive in	1
Jack in the Box	0
Whataburger	0
Hardees	0
Carl's Jr.	1
Five Guys	0
Culver's	1 ~~~
Inside View
~~~ What's the business case? Share of vegetarians/vegans in the US has been stable at about 8% for more than a decade [2]. However, spending on plant-based meat has been growing (6% in 2016) [3]. It is telling that plant based burgers have been becoming more prominent in the last couple of years being offered at a rising number of burger chains. [4] However, most of the chains to offer plant based burgers have been more minor ones like White Castle, Cheesecake Factory and the like. [5] How interested in McDonald's specifically? McDonald's has long offered exceptionally little for vegetarians/vegans (a grade of F- by PETA) [6] Yet, the proliferation of meatless patties in Europe suggest this is an area they are interested in. The fact that Burger King (the main competitor to McDonalds) has partnered with Impossible Foods suggests it's in McDonald's to field that threat. On the other hand, McDonald's may want to consciously create an image of a brand that specifically serves carnivores (their extremely low PETA score is consistent with that). But again, given their European experimentation, that doesn't seem likely (although, on the other other hand, McDonald's is known to adapt to local markets, e.g. with Maharaja Mac in India).  Meatless patties are becoming more well-known with the arrival of Impossible and Beyond burgers. That means that the public is becoming more comfortable with the idea. Given the fact that neither Impossible nor Beyond have flopped yet (Beyond is in fact doing well in the stock market) suggests that meatless patties are gaining at least some traction. To watch/consider further:

McDonald's is doing well from a corporate-health standard.  Stock price has been trending up for the past five years (more than doubled) despite the negative health image the chain has.  Suggests they don't require a large change in image or menu to continue doing well. Competition in the vegetarian/vegan niche dining options is being noticed by McD's, but the company is standing by prior to moving towards expanding or altering their menu.  Burger King has rolled out their Impossible Burger Whopper option to five states; expansion indicates it's currently profitable. Other chains are offering meatless protein options which may pull customers away from McD's. Americans appear to be eating less meat due to health and environmental concerns.  A JHU study from 2018 noted that 66% of consumers reported they cut down meat consumption, particularly red and processed meat.   While the signs point towards McD's adding a meatless burger to the menu, the question is when this will happen.  The scope of the change required to do this does not seem to map to the indicated timeline.  I see this as coming farther down the line.
